description: From Middle English pult, a variant of pulet, polet, from Old French poulet (“young fowl”), diminutive of poule (“hen”), from Latin pulla. For the development of the stressed vowel, see poultry.

entries.meaning: A young bird, a chick; now especially, a young game bird (turkey, partridge, grouse etc.). [from 14th c.]
examples: ‘I even questioned,’ said he, ‘whether there will not be, in about a week's time, some nice turkey powts.’
